content: spring vibes coffee sleeve by jen dickinson celebrate the return of color to the world with this simple and springy sleeve finished size fits standard take-away coffee cup approximately 6 5cm 2 ½ in across the base 11cm 4 ¼ in high difficulty easy hook 4mm us6 - 5mm us8 depending on your yarn and gauge yarn worsted weight yarn additional materials yarn needle scissors a cup to test the size stitch marker abbreviations american terms chain chain double_crochet double_crochet 2dc double_crochet twice into the same stitch single_crochet single_crochet 2sc single_crochet twice in same stitch slip_stitch slip_stitch * * repeat the instructions between the stars instructions make a magic loop or a slip knot that tightens when the tail is pulled round 1 chain 3 counts as a st double_crochet into loop 11 times pull the tail to tighten magic loop slip_stitch to top of ch3 count the stitches there should be 12 round 2 chain 3 counts as a st double_crochet into same stitch as the chains 2dc 11 times do not slip_stitch to the ch3 24 check time to do a size/gauge check compare the size of your circle with the base of the cup it should be aproximately the same size if your circle is too big try again with a smaller hook if it is too small try a bigger hook round 3 single_crochet into the ch3 from round 2 place stitch marker in single_crochet to mark the begining of the rounds single_crochet 23 times 2sc 25 rounds 4 - 15 continue to single_crochet around try the sleeve on the cup every 5 row or so it should be snug but not too tight like a sock depending on your gauge and yarn you may need to change to a larger hook towards the top when it is tall enough to hold comfortably in your hand start the picot border might not be exactly 15 rounds picot border *single_crochet ch2 slip_stitch into front loop of the single_crochet you have just made single_crochet in next stitch* repeat all the way around after the last picot instead of a single_crochet slip_stitch into the single_crochet of the first picot there should be 25 total stitches and 13 picots finishing cut the yarn and pull the tail through the loop that was on your hook to make a little knot weave in both your ends you re finished enjoy
